divisions.name: Appointment
divisions.description: Deals with appointment, transfer, and removal of Chief Justice and Judges of the Supreme Court and High Courts. Also responsible for setting up new High Courts, Benches of Supreme Court and High Courts, and increasing Judge strength of the Supreme Court and High Courts of India.
functions: Appointment of Chief Justice and Judges
Establishment of Benches of Supreme Court and High Courts

divisions.name: National Mission for Justice Delivery & Legal Reforms
divisions.description: Deals with pendency reduction, ease of doing business (enforcing contracts parameter), development of infrastructure facilities for District and subordinate courts, the Gram Nyayalaya scheme, Rule of Law Index, and Action Research for Judicial Reforms.
functions: Ease of doing business (enforcing contracts parameter)
Development of infrastructure facilities for District and subordinate courts

divisions.name: Access to Justice
divisions.description: Implements the "Designing Innovative Solutions for Holistic Access to Justice in India (DISHA)" scheme, which includes Tele-law, Nyaya Bandhu, Nyaya Mitra, and Legal Literacy & Legal Awareness Programme. Also deals with matters related to NALSA, including grant-in-aid, Annual Accounts of National Legal Aid Fund, Audit Report of the C&AG, Annual Report of NALSA and Legal Services Authorities of UT, and representations/grievances for legal aid.
functions: Implementation of DISHA scheme (Tele-law, Nyaya Bandhu, Nyaya Mitra, Legal Literacy & Legal Awareness Programme)
Laying of Annual Accounts of National Legal Aid Fund
Annual Report of NALSA and Legal Services Authorities of UT

divisions.name: eCourts
divisions.description: A Mission Mode Project using technology to enhance efficiency and speed of justice delivery in district and subordinate courts across India. Implemented jointly by the Department of Justice and eCommittee, Supreme Court of India.
functions: Computerization of district and subordinate courts
Enhanced judicial service for litigants and lawyers through technology
Improved ICT Infrastructure, video conferencing, access across multiple platforms
ICT provisioning for District Legal Service Authorities, Taluka Legal Service Committees, and State Judicial Academies

phases.name: Phase-I
phases.description: Approved in 2010, enabled computerization of 14,249 courts by 2015 at a cost of Rs. 639 crores.

phases.name: Phase-II
phases.description: Commissioned in 2015, focusing on enhanced judicial service for litigants and lawyers through technology.

phases.name: Phase-III
phases.description: Approved in 2023, aims for digital, online, and paperless courts through digitization of records and universalization of e-Filing/e-Payments.

divisions.name: Justice-I
divisions.description: Deals with pay, allowance, and pension of Supreme Court and High Court Judges, Judicial Pay Commission, Pecuniary Jurisdiction of Delhi District Courts, use of Hindi and regional languages in courts, and redressal of public grievances.
functions: Pay, allowance, and pension of Judges
Pecuniary Jurisdiction of Delhi District Courts
Use of Hindi and regional languages in courts

divisions.name: Justice-II
divisions.description: Deals with setting up Fast Track Special Courts for rape and POCSO Act cases, compiling case statistics, preparing proposals for Finance Commission, updating Citizen Charter, handling RTI applications, matters related to National Judicial Academy, Parliament Questions, and other miscellaneous issues.
functions: Setting up Fast Track Special Courts

divisions.name: Administration
divisions.description: Responsible for personnel/General administration of the Department of Justice, including budget, finance, audit, RTI, eOffice, training, Hindi/Rajbhasha matters, Swachhta Action Plan, and Parliamentary Matters coordination.

Functions.Details: Appointment, resignation, and removal of the Chief Justice of India, Judges of the Supreme Court, and High Courts, including their salaries, leave rights, pensions, and allowances.

Functions.Function: Constitution and Organization of Supreme Court
Functions.Details: Constitution and organization of the Supreme Court, excluding jurisdiction and powers, including contempt matters and fees.

Functions.Function: Constitution and Organization of High Courts
Functions.Details: Constitution and organization of High Courts and Courts of Judicial Commissioners, excluding provisions for officers and servants.
Constitution and organization of Courts in Union Territories and related fees.
Implementation of proposals recommended and approved under Finance Commission awards.
Collection of data on institution, disposal, and pendency of cases, and monitoring the status of under trial prisoners.
Initiate policy measures for judicial reforms.
Setting up and operationalization of the National Mission for Justice delivery and Legal reforms.
Setting up of Fast Track Special Courts for speedy trial and disposal of sexual offence cases.
Creation of the All India Judicial Service (AIJS).
Implementation of schemes for the development and modernization of judiciary infrastructure.
Enhancing the Department of Justice through e-office, statistical wing, and website revamping.
All matters related to the National Judicial Academy.
Achieving universal computerization of all District & Subordinate Court complexes in coordination with the eCommittee of the Supreme Court.
Implementation of the Central Sector Scheme 'Designing Innovative Solutions for Holistic Access to Justice in India (DISHA)'.
All matters related to the National Legal Services Authority (NALSA).

Responsibilities.Details: Responsible for appointing, transferring, and removing judges and setting up new High Courts and Supreme Court benches.
Implements schemes to develop infrastructure for the judiciary, including special courts for speedy trials.
Provides legal aid to the poor and ensures access to justice.
Develops policies for judicial reforms and modernizes court procedures.
Provides financial assistance to the National Judicial Academy for training judicial officers.
Advises ministries on legal matters, including law and constitutional interpretation.
Conducts cases on behalf of the Central and State Governments in Supreme Court and High Courts.
Maintains reciprocal arrangements with foreign countries for service of summons and execution of decrees.

Overview.Objective: Improve physical infrastructure of Subordinate Courts and housing for Judicial Officers.
Overview.Coverage: All States and Union Territories (UTs), excluding High Court buildings.

CurrentStatus.InterimExtension: Until 31.03.2021 or Fifteenth Finance Commission recommendations

ProactiveSteps: Identify infrastructural needs with five-year and annual action plans.
Complete projects pending for three or more years on a mission mode basis.
Timely completion of court complexes and judges' accommodation.
Constitute committees for monitoring and coordination.
Monthly reporting and monitoring of work and fund utilization.
Online progress updates by all High Courts.

JudicialOfficers.Responsibility: State Governments and High Courts are responsible for filling vacancies

DistrictAndSubordinateCourts.Note: Vacancy positions available on the Department of Justice website.

introduction.description: To become a judge or magistrate in India is a highly respected position, associated with responsibility and pride in a democratic society.

stepsToBecomeJudge.description: Obtain an LL.B degree from a recognized University/College.

options.description: LL.B degree pursued after graduation in any stream.
Integrated B.A./BBA/B.Com/B.Sc LL.B degree pursued after class 12.

stepsToBecomeJudge.description: Compete in the State Judicial Services Examination conducted by respective State Governments.

requirements.qualification: LL.B degree with practice in High Court or subordinate courts.
LL.B degree with first attempt pass or LL.M with 55% marks.

categories.name: Members of Ministerial Staff of High Court
Legal Assistant or above in Government Legal Sector

appointment.description: Appointed by the President after consultation.
qualifications: 5 years as a judge of a High Court or succession of High Courts
10 years as an advocate in High Courts
Distinguished jurist recognized by the President

appointment.description: Appointed by the President after consultation with the Chief Justice and Governor.
qualifications: 10 years as an advocate in High Courts

appointment.description: Appointments made by the Governor in consultation with the High Court.
qualifications: Member of the judicial service of the State
7 years of practice as a lawyer

conclusion.message: There are multiple pathways to becoming a judge in India, requiring expertise in law and comprehensive legal knowledge. The retirement age is 65 for Supreme Court judges and 62 for High Court judges.

app_info.description: eCourts Services App is useful to Citizen, Litigants, Lawyers, Police, Government Agencies, and other Institutional Litigants.

services.name: Search by CNR
services.description: CNR is a unique number assigned to each case filed in District and Taluka Courts in the Country, through Case Information System. Simply by entering the CNR one can get the current status and details of the case.

services.name: Case Status
services.description: Case Status can be searched by various options like Case Number, Party Name, Filing Number, FIR Number, Advocate Name, Relevant Act of the Case, and Case Type.
details: Initial search result of case status is displayed with Case Number and names of parties.
Case details include information of Case Type, Filing Number, Filing Date, Registration Number, Registration Date, and CNR Number.
Case Status includes information of First Hearing Date, Next Hearing Date, State of Case, Court Number, and Designation of Judge.

features.History of Case Hearing: Shows entire history of the case from first date of hearing to current date of hearing. When clicking the date of hearing, the business recorded on the clicked date is displayed.
features.Judgment and Order: Shows links of all judgments and orders passed and uploaded in the selected case. These can be clicked to view the full content.

services.name: Cause List
services.description: Generates cause list of selected Court. By default, the current date is selected for generating cause list. However, one can change this date to any recent future date.

services.name: My Cases
services.description: Allows litigants or lawyers to save cases of interest, which will be shown under My Cases tab with details like the establishment and number of cases saved.

features.Today's Cases: Provides the facility to view only today’s listed cases from all saved cases.
features.Remove Case: Gives option to remove a case when viewing case details.
features.Refresh: Updates the information saved under My Cases. If a case is not updated due to connection issues, the app will show 'connection error'.

services.name: Advocate
services.description: Information can be searched by the name of the Advocate or their Bar Code. It generates a list of all cases associated with the advocate when their Bar Code is entered.

services.name: Date Case List
services.description: Generates a unique cause list for all cases of an advocate listed before all courts in the complex.

backup.description: Backup facility is provided to take a backup of saved cases on a mobile device.

features.Export: Backup can be taken in text file format on the device.
features.Import: Data can be restored in the My Cases tab.

generalSteps.description: Enter your login ID and password

supremeCourtSteps.description: Go to the Supreme Court of India's official website
Go to the e-filing registration page
Pay the required court fees and printing charges
Refer to the user manual on the website before filing the case

guidelines.description: The petition must be typed in double space, justified, and in 14 font size and courier format
Only corrected pages should be uploaded when re-filing
The online e-filing should not be encrypted or watermarked
The e-filed documents should not contain any malware, virus, trojan horse, or spam-ware
All the e-filed documents should be legible and free of all annotations, track changes, or markings

steps.description: Open URL
Choose Fine as Payment type
Note: Fine can only be paid for existing cases
Identify existing case by choosing from 'CNR Number' OR 'Case Number'
CNR Number is a unique 16-digit alphanumeric number assigned to each case
steps.additionalInfo: Find CNR number from eCourt services website, Kiosks in court premises, or contact court staff

steps.description: To find Case Particulars through CNR Number, enter the 16 Digit CNR number and click GO
To find case particulars through Case Number, select State (Orissa), Relevant District, Relevant Establishment, Case Type, then enter Case Number and Year, and click GO
Choose the name of the party depositing Fine from dropdown list, or enter new party name if not listed
Enter Amount of Fine and Mobile Number
Select the check box for 'I Agree to above Terms and Conditions'
Click on Generate OTP and an OTP will be sent to your mobile
Enter OTP and click on 'Verify' button. Regenerate OTP after 2 minutes if not received
After verification, you will be redirected to IFMS Odisha (e-Receipt 2.0) for payment
Choose Payment Gateway option to pay via Credit/Debit Card or Net banking and click 'Proceed to Payment'
Select payment option, provide required details, and click 'Pay Now'
Make the payment to complete the transaction
Payment successful message will be displayed by the bank
Bank will redirect back to IFMS Odisha (e-Receipt 2.0) displaying a successful message and Challan Receipt
Click 'Back to Department website' button to return to ePay website
Acknowledgment slip from eCourts ePay will be displayed with options to 'Print' or 'Download PDF'
steps.note: This PDF is required as proof of payment of Fine

steps.description: Use the ACKNOWLEDGMENT slip as proof of payment and submit it in the concerned court for verification

paymentProcess.description: e-Filing of cases requires the option for electronic payment of fees including court fees, fines, and penalties payable to the Consolidated Fund.

paymentTypes.description: Fees associated with filing cases in court.
Additional fees imposed for certain violations.

appDetails.name: eCourts Services Mobile App
appDetails.description: Revolutionary court information tool in the country.

overview.concept: The eCourts Project was conceptualized based on the National Policy and Action Plan for Implementation of ICT in the Indian Judiciary – 2005.
overview.vision: To transform the Indian Judiciary through ICT enablement of Courts.

governance.purpose: Assist in formulating a national policy on computerization of the Indian Judiciary.

funding.monitoredBy: Department of Justice, Ministry of Law and Justice, Government of India

projectGoals: Develop, install & implement decision support systems in courts.
Automate processes for transparency in information accessibility.
Enhance judicial productivity to make justice delivery affordable and reliable.

achievements: Computerization of District and Taluka Court Complexes.
Installation of hardware and Case Information Software (CIS).
phaseI.training: Judicial Officers trained by Master Trainers.

enhancements: Additional hardware and systems per Court Room.
Computerization of Legal Services Authorities and Judicial Academies.
keyFeatures: ePayment gateways for court fees and fines.

dataCoverage.pendingCases: Over 7 crore pending and disposed of cases.

eCommitteeComposition.patron: Hon’ble the Chief Justice of India

members.responsibilities: Implementation and application of Judicial Processes and automation.
Monitoring and coordination of the eCommittee and PMU.
Management and monitoring of Human Resources provisioned through the Project.
Customization and deployment of Operating Systems and Application Software.

highCourtRoles.implementingAgency: High Court as the Implementing Agency for project implementation.

centralProjectCoordinator.description: District Judge or Senior Civil Judge coordinating project tasks.

structure.districtCourtComputerCommittee: Monitors project implementation at District level.
structure.nodalOfficer: Designated Judicial Officer as point of contact for project progress.

features.description: Filter judgments based on the bench that delivered the decision.
Search judgments according to the type of case.
Search using the specific case number.
Filter judgments by the year they were delivered.
Search for judgments using the name of the petitioner or respondent.
Filter judgments based on the judge's name.
Search based on the legal act under which the case was filed.
Filter judgments by specific sections of law.
Search for judgments within a specific date range.
Conduct a comprehensive search of the judgment text.

fastTrackSpecialCourts.objective: Championing the safety and security of women and girl children.

legislation.name: Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2018
provisions: Stringent punishment for perpetrators of rape, including death penalty.

monitoringFramework.onlineMonitoring: Created for monthly monitoring of case statistics.
monitoringFramework.reviewMeetings: Regular meetings with Registrar Generals of High Courts and State functionaries.

eFilingSystem.description: Online system to file cases in Indian courts.

features.description: File a case or application from home or office.
Upload pleadings and documents in PDF format and e-sign online.
Check the status of your case online.

initiatives.description: Allow litigants and advocates to participate remotely, saving time and manpower.
Changes to CrPC and CPC to reduce adjournments and rationalize compoundable offenses.
Address crimes against women and children, with jurisdiction over homicide, sexual crimes, and abortion.

eFilingSystem.prompt: Please ask about e-filing to get a prompt reply about it for further info.

establishmentRecommendation.details: The 14th Finance Commission recommended the establishment of 1,800 FTCs.

implementationPeriod.details: States were encouraged to establish FTCs during this period.

setup.collaboration: State governments work with High Courts to establish FTCs.
setup.responsibility: State governments handle the operational aspects.

jurisdiction: Civil cases related to senior citizens
Property cases pending for more than five years

methods: Regular review meetings with Registrar Generals of High Courts

TeleLawServices.description: Tele-Law service provides legal advice and consultation at the pre-litigation stage.

steps.details: Visit a Common Service Center (CSC) and inquire about the Tele-Law service. The VLE will provide information and register you as an applicant.
The VLE will upload your details to the Tele-Law portal information form.
The VLE or Panel Legal Volunteer (PLV) will assist you in securing an appointment with a Panel Lawyer.
You can connect with a Panel Lawyer via video conferencing, chat, or telephone at the CSC. An SMS with your appointment details will be sent to your registered mobile number.

TeleLaw.description: Tele-Law connects individuals with legal experts for advice and consultation at the pre-litigation stage.

steps.details: Individuals go to a CSC and inquire about the Tele-Law service.
The VLE provides information about the Tele-Law service and registers the individual as an applicant.
The VLE uploads the individual's details to the Tele-Law portal.
The VLE or a Panel Legal Volunteer (PLV) assists in scheduling an appointment with a Panel Lawyer.
Individuals connect with the Panel Lawyer through video conferencing, chat, or telephone at the CSC.
An SMS with appointment details is sent to the individual's registered mobile number.

features.availability: Accessible through Common Service Centers and the Tele-Law Mobile App.
features.targetAudience: Individuals seeking legal advice before litigation.

currentStatus.note: Continuously expanding to improve access to legal services.

DepartmentOfJustice.name: Department of Justice
DepartmentOfJustice.address: Jaisalmer House, 26, Mansingh Road, New Delhi-110011

CscEGovernance.name: CSC e-Governance Services India Ltd.
CscEGovernance.address: 4th Floor, Electronic Niketan, DIT Programme Management Unit 6, CGO Complex, Lodhi Road, South Delhi -110003

steps.details: A list of CSCs and their contact details will appear.
Call the PLV's number or visit the CSC's address.
Inquire with Village Headmen for PLV details.

TeleLawContactInfo.serviceDescription: Tele-Law provides legal advice and consultation before court proceedings, connecting individuals with Panel Lawyers via video conferencing or phone at Common Service Centres (CSCs).

steps.action: Go to the e-Challan portal at echallan.parivahan.gov.in.
Select 'Check Challan Status' from the drop-down menu under 'Check Online Service'.
Enter the required details: challan number, vehicle number, or driver's license number.
After the transaction is complete, you'll receive a transaction ID.
You can also check traffic fines using the mParivahan mobile app.
Check the details of the fine on the challan and gather evidence to support your case.
File an online or offline representation to the concerned authority within the stipulated time frame.
The authority will review your representation and evidence and pass an order.
If not satisfied with the decision, file an appeal to a higher authority within the prescribed timelines.
The appeal process may involve a personal hearing, after which a final decision will be passed.

steps.note: Adhere to timelines and procedures to avoid rejection of your appeal.

details: Accumulation of additional fines and penalties.
Possible legal action including court summons.
Impounding of vehicle or restrictions on vehicle registration.
Negative impact on credit rating if fines remain unpaid.

ConstitutionalBasis: Article 39A provides for free legal aid to the poor and weaker sections.
Articles 14 and 22(1) ensure equality before law and promote justice.

LegalServicesAuthoritiesAct.purpose: Establish a nationwide network for providing free and competent legal services.

NALSA.description: National Legal Services Authority (NALSA) monitors and evaluates implementation of legal aid programmes.

MainFunctions: Provide free and competent legal services to eligible persons.
Organize Lok Adalats for amicable settlement of disputes.
Conduct legal awareness camps in rural areas.

servicesIncluded: Payment of court fees and other charges.
Obtaining certified copies of orders and documents.
Preparation of appeals and related documents.
Eligibility: Annual income not exceeding Rs. 1 lakh (Rs. 5 lakh for Supreme Court)

LokAdalats.description: A forum for amicable settlement of disputes.
LokAdalats.status: Statutory status under the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987.
LokAdalats.bindingEffect: An award made is deemed a decree of a civil court and is final.

eLokAdalat.description: Conceptualized for improved access to justice during COVID.

details.purpose: Functions as Central Authority under the Legal Services Authorities Act.

Online.description: You can file an RTI application online for the DoJ through the eFiling portal.

steps.action: Provide details like your name, address, email address, and phone number.
Include a description of the information sought and any supporting documents.

ByPostEmailInPerson.description: You can also file an RTI application by post, email, or in person.

steps.action: Write your application in English, Hindi, or the official language of the area.
Send it to the Public Information Officer (PIO) of the DoJ.
Pay the application fee when submitting the application.

ApproachAuthorities.Description: Depending on territorial and subject matter jurisdiction, individuals should approach:

Authorities.name: Taluk Legal Services Committee
Authorities.location: In the premises of the Court in that Taluk

Authorities.name: District Legal Services Authority
Authorities.location: In the premises of the District Court in the District Headquarters

Authorities.name: State Legal Services Authority
Authorities.location: For particular cases maintained at State level

Authorities.name: High Court Legal Services Committee
Authorities.location: In the premises of the concerned High Court

Authorities.name: Supreme Court Legal Services Committee
Authorities.location: For cases before the Hon’ble Supreme Court

ApproachAuthorities.ApplicationSubmission: Applications can be submitted at the front office of each authority or online via NALSA's website.

Offline.Description: Fill up a ready-made form available at the nearest Legal Services Authority.
Details: Submit the form physically or by post.
You can also write a simple application including necessary details.

Online.Description: Send an application via email or the online application form.

Oral.Description: Make an application orally with assistance from a paralegal volunteer or officer.

DocumentationRequired.OnlineInfo: Relevant document requirements are provided on NALSA's website.

Charges.Description: There are no charges for obtaining or submitting the application form for free legal aid.
Charges.LegalAdvice: You can call or visit the Legal Services Authority office for legal advice without cost.

AssistanceForIlliterate.Description: Illiterate persons can be assisted by Legal Services Authorities or para-legal volunteers.
AssistanceForIlliterate.Process: Volunteers can fill out forms for applicants, who just need to affix their signature or thumb impression.

Expenses.Description: No expenses for process fees, drafting, typing, clerkage, or lawyer fees are incurred by the applicant.

OtherAuthorities.Description: Check respective websites for office hours.

ProceduralLawAmendments.Description: Amendments introduced to speed up the disposal of civil and criminal cases.
KeyChanges: Limiting the number of adjournments that can be granted to each party in civil trials.
Allowing the service of summons by email, fax, speed post, courier, or directly through the plaintiff.
Allowing the use of audio and video technology in criminal cases.

NationalMissionForJudicialReforms.Description: The NMJR Division focuses on reducing pendency, improving ease of doing business, and developing infrastructure for subordinate courts.

FastTrackSpecialCourts.Description: Scheme to set up special courts for the speedy trial of sensitive cases.

EcourtProject.Description: Initiative to computerize various courts across the country.

LegalAid.Description: The DoJ provides legal aid to the poor and aims to improve access to justice.

CentrallySponsoredScheme.Description: Scheme for the development of infrastructure facilities for the judiciary since 1993-94.
EligibilityCriteria: Indication of project start and end dates

Objectives: Increasing access by reducing delays and arrears

StepsForTimelyEnforcement.CommercialBenches: Set up in Delhi and Bombay High Courts.
StepsForTimelyEnforcement.PecuniaryJurisdiction: Reduced to Rs 3 lakhs from Rs. 1 crore.
StepsForTimelyEnforcement.RandomAllocation: Automatic allocation of cases in Dedicated Commercial Courts.
StepsForTimelyEnforcement.AdjournmentRule: Compliance with maximum three adjournment rules enforced.
StepsForTimelyEnforcement.EfilingService: Launched in Dedicated Commercial Courts of Delhi and Mumbai.

RuleOfLawIndex.Description: Measures the rule of law in practice based on accountability, laws, process, and access to justice.

DataGovernanceQualityIndex.Description: Enhances data preparedness and development of data systems.
